name: ban

B2 to forbid (= refuse to allow) something, especially officially: The film was banned (= the government prevented it from being shown) in several countries. [ + from + -ing verb ] She was banned from driving for two years.

B2 an official order that prevents something from happening: There should be a ban on talking loudly in cinemas.
More examplesFewer examplesThe ban on media reporting during the election has made some people question the fairness of the election .The severe drought has led to a hosepipe ban in eastern England.The council has imposed a ban on alcohol in the city parks.The British Medical Association is/are campaigning for a complete ban on tobacco advertising.At last they've lifted the ban on jeans at the club.

an official order that prevents someone doing something, or something from happening: ban on sth The police are enforcing the state's ban on the sale of fireworks.impose/enforce/lift a ban They have now lifted the ban on the export of live animals to Europe.
